text: hi everyone kathany kauftano here the
internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new bleachers
record take the sadness out of saturday
night this is a brand
new record from singer songwriter
multi-instrumentalist
in-demand producer mr jack antonoff this
being his third record under the
bleachers name
his first for this decade and it'll be
interesting to see what the next
10 years for jack holds considering how
dominant he was in the 2010s
there was his last record with fun a
couple of bleachers records with great
singles on him he's also become a go-to
producer for the likes of lord taylor
swift
saint vincent and now he's a grammy
winner five
times over so yeah there just seems to
be no stopping jack at this point and
there's even some really impressive
material on this new lp2
which in his own words is an album about
joy and rejecting feelings of
negativity depression boredom and for
the most part this album feels like that
yeah
especially on tracks like how dare you
want more and stop
making this hurt which are really two of
my favorite singles of the year
the former feels like a collaboration
between elvis costello paul simon and
david byrne
backed up with some big city saxophones
the
sax and guitar trades over the bridge of
the song are fantastic
this is easily one of the most exuberant
and rockin tracks i've heard in 2021
then stop making this hurt is a true
blue anthem with its glossy pianos
booming drums
grand chorus vocals and it's an anthem
with a purpose too kind of begging the
world to let up with all of the just
discontent and hatred pain and suffering
and there aren't just big sounds on this
lp but some big names too
the song secret life sports a lana del
rey appearance although it is a subtle
one
with jack singing really intimately over
this warm relaxed
velvet underground style instrumental
and as the track progresses he subtly
adds more layers that are a bit more
spacious to bring the song body and
dynamics
namely that lana background vocal and
some of those wailing guitar tones
and i like the lyrics of the song a lot
too it's all about finding
solace and serenity for a love or some
kind of intimacy to
grow and just be fostered then there's
bruce springsteen on chinatown now bruce
has long been an influence on jack's
music a huge one
so i imagine this is a pretty huge
moment for him but in
listening to this track as like an
initial teaser to this record i was not
crazy about it mostly because of the
abusive amount of effects
and reverb laced into this thing the
vocals and instrumentation sound so
blobby and
smudged and not in an experimental or
interesting way
it's like listening to my bloody
valentine producer springsteen ballad
and completely smothered the song out in
the process now granted
i enjoy the track a bit more now or i
appreciate it more now than i did when i
first heard it but i don't know if
that's because it's grown on me or
because i'm
offended even more by the increased
levels of effects and delay on the song
big life
why does everything on this song sound
so springy and disorienting and
the volume is constantly changing with
certain elements of the mix too to the
point that it kind of hurts to listen to
i'm kind of blown away that a track of
this
like audio quality and production
quality is on the same record
as some of the other tracks here this
just seems like too
far gone don't go dark is more pure
springsteen worship though there's not
so much delay
on it that it ruins the track and for
some reason the exaggerated vibrato of
jack's voice
and the yelpiness of his singing too
kind of reminds me of like spencer krug
of
wolf parade fame which is not a bad
thing i'm just saying it's kind of an
interesting
vocal delivery to hear over this almost
like
jangly arena rock style sound then with
the last leg of this lp
the momentum really begins to trail off
as the instrumentals get more mellow
more skeletal and this change in pace
does come
a little as a shock considering the
pacing of the songs just prior and i
guess how short this album
is overall in terms of flow it's a very
quick turndown
there's the acoustic 45 which i think is
a quality tune for sure
jack gives a fiery vocal and you know
acoustic guitar performance on this
track
uh but it's one that he puts so much
heart in i can't help but as i'm
listening to it
just imagine how a full band would sound
behind it because it's a pretty gutsy
again
performance on the song and it just
seems like
uh i don't know only halfway done with
it being as stripped back as it is
then the refined and gorgeous
orchestrations on the track strange
behavior
are quite nice but i feel like this song
only adds to this
feeling of aesthetically this whole
record just being like a hodgepodge of
sounds and
production and sound qualities and
instrumental palettes the opening and
closing tracks
songwriting-wise are almost like motifs
that are underscored by
layers of horns or strings and they're
both pleasant while they're on but
neither of them do a great job of like
setting the tone for the record or
closing up shops so succinctly that it
feels like we're
having a strong moment of finality here
look there are some great tracks on this
thing and for the songs that aren't so
great
there are at least some really good
ideas and intentions
backing all of them up but the full
potential of this lp is still
severely kneecapped by a complete and
utter lack of focus consistency and
quality control
this whole thing feels like i'm
listening to a compilation more than an
album which is kind of odd because i got
the sense from previous bleachers
records as well as jack's
work with other artists that he is a bit
more
methodical than he is showing himself to
be here feeling a light too decent six
on this one tran position have you given
this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
